0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono: Influenza; Prophylaxis: 1 dose (0.5 mL) IM once annually

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: safety and effectiveness not established in pediatric patients

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono: severe allergic reactions (eg, anaphylaxis) to any vaccine component

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Guillain-Barr syndrome within 6 weeks of a previously administered influenza vaccine; evaluate benefit/risk before administration
  • immunocompromised patients, including those receiving immunosuppressive therapy; immune response may be decreased
  • report adverse events to the Vaccine Adverse Event Reporting System (VAERS) at 1-800-822-7967 or http://www.vaers.hhs.gov

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Injection site pain (19% to 37%)
  • Musculoskeletal:Myalgia (8% to 11%)
  • Neurologic:Headache (10% to 15%)
  • Other:Fatigue (13% to 15%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Pleuropericarditis, acute
  • Immunologic:Anaphylaxis

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: The influenza virus vaccine recombinant contains recombinant hemagglutinin (HA) proteins of 3 influenza virus strains that are considered likely to be circulating in the United States during the influenza season for which the vaccine has been standardized. The HA proteins function as antigens to induce a humoral immune response.

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• General Information
    for IM injection only
  • Intramuscular
    • shake vial gently before use
    • administer IM, preferably in the deltoid muscle
    • do not mix with any other vaccine in the same syringe or vial

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono: no specific monitoring has been determined

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono: Drug may cause injection site pain, redness or swelling, headache, fatigue, and myalgia.
